dsls.markdown: # Creativity + Code #### **Welcome to the exciting world of coding, where creativity knows no bounds!** #### This professional learning module invites you to discover the possibilities of coding for creativity. With a focus on simple basics, we'll guide you through the process of crafting engaging animations that can later be enhanced into stories and interactive games. ## Take the pre-survey ##### Code.org values and is responsive to feedback. Please fill out this short pre-survey to tell us about who you are and how we can best support you. Take the pre-survey ## In this module, you will: * #### Identify and explain fundamental CS concepts, including sprites, events and behaviors. * #### Demonstrate the application of event-based programming. * #### Create a program using sprites, events, and behaviors. ### **Suggested time:** 60 minutes ## Let's get started!

https://studio.code.org/s/self-paced-pl-.long_instructions:
## Event-based programming
#### You will begin your journey in Sprite Lab. **Sprite Lab** is a block-based programming environment that allows students to create simple animations and games with objects and characters. #### Sprite Lab uses a type of coding called **event-based programming**. Instead of just following a strict sequence of instructions, the flow of an **event-based program** is determined by events such as user actions, like clicking a button. #### _This approach is commonly found in interactive applications like video games._

dsls.markdown: # Overview of Sprite Lab #### The next lesson will provide you with the basics to get you started on your program using Sprite Lab. ## You will: * #### Learn about sprites and how to add them to your program. * #### Get acquainted with the costume feature to change the look of your sprite. * #### Add a background to your program. * #### Learn how to customize sprites and backgrounds. ## Let's Get Started with sprites! ### **Suggested time:** 15 minutes

https://studio.code.org/s/self-paced-pl-.short_instructions: Match the bunny's fur to its environment.
https://studio.code.org/s/self-paced-pl-.long_instructions:
Note: The size of the instruction box can be adjusted by dragging the symbol on the bottom of the box.

A sprite is a digital character or object that can move and do things in a computer program.
Costumes make coding more creative and allow sprites to have different appearances.

Using a background is way to enhance the stage of your program and can be adjusted based on events to enhance your program.

Practice adding a sprite and background and changing the costume in this lesson from the CS Connections Animal Adaptations curriculum.


#### **Rabbits have adapted different fur colors to blend into new environments.** - #### Drag and connect a set background block under when run - #### Drag and connect a new sprite block to your code - #### **Change** the sprite costume to model the adaptation by using the drop down arrow to toggle to the desired costume.

Press the run button under the stage on the left side of your screen to test your code.

* * * **Bonus:** Try modeling the adaptation in another environment. (Change the background and costume)

authored_hints.change costume dropdown:
Click the dropdown menu to choose a new sprite costume. 

[][0]

https://studio.code.org/s/self-paced-pl-.short_instructions: Add a new sprite and change it's location.
https://studio.code.org/s/self-paced-pl-.long_instructions:
While adding your sprite, you may have noticed the X,Y coordinates in the play space. Note that this grid is different from coordinate grids you may have seen in math class. In this grid, the bottom left corner is the starting point, marked as 0,0. As your characters move to the right, the X number gets bigger, and as they go up, the Y number gets bigger.

Practice moving the sprite to set locations.


#### **Rabbits have _adapted_ the color of their fur to blend into their environment and hide from predators.** - #### Add a make new sprite block to your code. - #### Click the location pin to move the sprite to a hiding place. - #### Add a new sprite as close as you can to the following location: **(95,75)** - #### Add another new sprite as close as you can to the following location: **(300,100)** - #### Press Run when you are finished.

To change a sprite's location, click the pin on the location block, then click where you want it to go.

https://studio.code.org/s/self-paced-pl-.short_instructions: Show the elephant's adaptation in size with the set size block.
https://studio.code.org/s/self-paced-pl-.long_instructions:
Let’s learn how to make your program more engaging and creative with the say block. The say block is a way for your sprite to "speak" bringing your programs to life with words, messages, or even silly comments.


#### **Elephants have evolved to be much larger than their main predators, the lion.** - #### set the size of the elephant sprite. - #### Add a say block that explains the elephant's adaptation. - #### Click Run to test your code. #### **Hint:** You must add a sprite before you can use the say block. Make sure the sprite in the say block matches the sprite you added.

https://studio.code.org/s/self-paced-pl-.long_instructions:
## Uploading your own images #### An exciting way to enhance the creativity of your project is to upload your own images. You can upload images from your computers to customize your projects with your own sprites and backgrounds using the upload feature.

Teacher Tip: Notice that a safety prompt and check box appear when using the upload feature. This reminds you and your students about online privacy to ensure students are aware they should not share any identifiable information, like their full name or address, in any of their photos.


#### **Note:** Images must be smaller than 100 Kb before trying to upload. #### Checkout this video to see how to upload your own images.

This level is an example from the Coding Interactive Maps module from the CS Connections curriculum. In it, students will practice uploading a custom feature to their maps.


#### **Customize your sprite costume and background** #### Try it! Use the upload feature to add images for a **sprite costume** and a **background** from your computer.
- #### Click on the **costumes tab** on the top left of your screen to get started. - #### Then, click on the **new costume icon** to explore the library of sprites or add your own! - #### Run the code, then wait for the "Finish" button to appear to continue on. [][0]

answers.text: You can add a custom sprite by uploading an image in the costume tab.
You cannot change the location of a sprite.
A sprite and background are the same thing.
It is not possible to customize the look of a sprite.
You can change the look of a sprite by changing its costume.

questions.text: Pick the two statements that are true about sprites in Sprite Lab:

dsls.title: Check for Understanding: Sprites and Backgrounds

dsls.markdown: # Programming with Events #### Now that you have set up your program with the background and sprites, you will learn how to make your program interactive. ## In this lesson, you will: * #### Learn about events and event-based programming. * #### Practice using events with different types of event blocks. * #### Create an interactive program using events. * #### Debug a program to make it work properly. ### **Suggested time:** 20 minutes ## Let's get started!

https://studio.code.org/s/self-paced-pl-.long_instructions: ## What are Events? #### Events are actions that cause something to happen. In code, events allow user interaction, like the arrow button being clicked to cause a sprite to move. #### An event block is a block that, when triggered, causes a specific chunk of code to run. In Sprite Lab, these blocks are green. You will notice event blocks are _not connected_ to the main section of your code. #### This video is part of Code.org's Hello World! Visit Hello World! for more information.

https://studio.code.org/s/self-paced-pl-.short_instructions: We can also stop a sprite's behavior.
https://studio.code.org/s/self-paced-pl-.long_instructions:
The lessons in this part of the module come from our Computer Science Connections: Animal Adaptations curriculum.

Teacher tip: Students sometimes get confused that the event block is not connected to the main code. Remind your students that events are separate segments of code that wait for a certain event to happen to be initiated.


The first type of event we will practice with is a when sprite clicked block. This will trigger certain actions to happen when the Sprite is clicked.

#### **Note:** _Behaviors will continue until you code it to stop._ - #### Set up a new event when sprite clicked. - #### Add a sprite stops block to the event. - #### Click Run then **click on the sprite** to stop the behavior. * * * #### **Bonus:** Program another sprite to **begin** and **stop** behaviors when clicked.

Another type of event is a when __ pressed event. This event causes the sprite to react based on an assigned keyboard button being pressed. For example, you can program the sprite to move to the right every time the right arrow button is pressed.


#### **Giraffes have adapted to have very long necks so they can reach the leaves in tall trees.** - #### Add a new when up pressed event anywhere in the workspace. - #### Connect a change costume block under the new event. - #### Click Run then press the **up arrow** to test it!

A third type of event is when sprite touches. This event is used when sprites are in motion. The event will be triggered when the sprites locations match.


#### **Octopuses change color to be camouflaged in their environment!** - #### Add a `when sprite touches`(#6AF36C) event anywhere in the workspace. - #### Connect a `change costume`(#5ED5DD) block so it changes color to blend in. - #### Click `Run`(#FFBD46) then use **arrow keys** to move the octopus to the plant. #### **Hint:** Pay close attention to the sprites selected in the code blocks. Make sure the sprites correctly match. * * * #### **_Bonus:_** Add another `when sprite touches`(#6AF36C) event with code to model the octopus changing color to blend in with other parts of the environment.

https://studio.code.org/s/self-paced-pl-.long_instructions:
## Debugging #### In computer science, **debugging** refers to finding and fixing problems in computer programs. It's like being a detective for computers. Look at the code and figure out what's going wrong so you can make the program work just the way you want it to. Bugs, or **problems in our code**, are common and expected. Don't feel bad if your code doesn't work correctly the first time. Coding and debugging help build **persistence**. ## Vocabulary #### **Bug** - Part of a program that does not work correctly. #### **Debugging** - Finding and fixing problems in an algorithm or program. #### **Persistence** - Not giving up.
#### Watch the video below to learn more about debugging.

https://studio.code.org/s/self-paced-pl-.short_instructions: Code the octopus to change color when it moves to the sea grass or coral.
https://studio.code.org/s/self-paced-pl-.long_instructions:
Teacher Tip: Encourage your students to share common bugs they have experienced with their code. Build discussions around debugging strategies.


#### **Octopuses change color to be camouflaged in their environment!** - #### Debug this code so that the octopus changes color when it touches one of the sea plants. * * * #### **_Bonus:_** Add another `when sprite touches`(#6AF36C) event with code to model the octopus changing color to blend in with other parts of the environment.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding events in sprite lab?

dsls.markdown: # Programming with Behaviors #### So far you have learned to set up your program with sprites and backgrounds and how to use events to make your program interactive. In this lesson, you will learn how to animate your sprite using behaviors. ## In this lesson, you will: * #### Learn about using behavior blocks in your program. * #### Practice using different behavior blocks. * #### Create an interactive program using behaviors. * #### Combine your knowledge of events and behaviors to make a creative program. ### **Suggested time:** 15 minutes ## Let's get started!

https://studio.code.org/s/self-paced-pl-.long_instructions: #### Take a look at how you can make your code more creative using behavior blocks in Sprite Lab.

https://studio.code.org/s/self-paced-pl-.short_instructions: Let's learn to animate sprites using behaviors.
https://studio.code.org/s/self-paced-pl-.long_instructions:
Teacher Tip: A common bug when students program behaviors is not matching the sprite in a behavior block to a sprite that exists. Be sure students create a sprite before they try to code a behavior and double check that the sprites match in the dropdown boxes.


#### **Animate sprites with a behavior. Behaviors are actions that happen over and over while the program runs.** - #### Use a new sprite begins block to animate one of the sprites. - #### Then choose a behavior from the list to add to make your sprite start moving. - #### Click Run to see the sprite begin the behavior. * * * #### **Bonus:** Add some more behaviors to your program!

dsls.markdown: # Behavior Blocks #### Behavior blocks animate sprites. These are special blocks that allow sprites to complete specific actions. The behavior blocks make it easier for beginning coders to use more complex actions. ## Let's take a look at this *growing* behavior. #### By adding the 'sprite begins' block, after run is pressed, the sprite will slowly get bigger.

# Behavior Blocks ## Let's see what is behind the scenes of this coding block. #### When you click on the blue edit tile, you can see that this behavior block has a continuous loop that changes the size of the sprite by 1.
#### In summary, the behavior blocks help simplify complex code and easily animate our programs.
## Let's explore behavior blocks on the next level.

https://studio.code.org/s/self-paced-pl-.short_instructions: Code the first move in the bird's silly dance.
https://studio.code.org/s/self-paced-pl-.long_instructions: #### **Dancing is a behavior many animals do to get attention or show they're the boss.** - #### First, choose your background environment and bird costume for your sprite. - #### Then, add a sprite begins behavior block and choose a behavior for the bird's first dance move. - #### Click Run to see the start of the dance! #### **Hint:** Make sure the bird you selected in the new sprite block matches the bird in the behavior block.

authored_hints.dance:
You can choose any behavior from the drop down list.
[][0]

behavior_descriptions.move a sprite if the user is pressing th: move a sprite if the user is pressing the arrow keys
behavior_descriptions.rotate a sprite to its left: rotate a sprite to its left
behavior_descriptions.rotate a sprite to its right: rotate a sprite to its right
behavior_descriptions.change the size of a sprite: change the size of a sprite
behavior_descriptions.randomly change the size of a sprite: randomly change the size of a sprite
behavior_descriptions.move a sprite across the screen, reversi: move a sprite across the screen, reversing direction if it touches the edges
behavior_descriptions.randomly change the vertical position of: randomly change the vertical position of a sprite
behavior_descriptions.randomly set the rotation of a sprite: randomly set the rotation of a sprite
behavior_descriptions.Move a sprite to the left across the scr: Move a sprite to the left across the screen. When it goes off the left side of the screen, move it back to the right side of the screen.
behavior_descriptions.Move a sprite to the right across the sc: Move a sprite to the right across the screen. When it goes off the right side of the screen, move it back to the left side of the screen.
behavior_descriptions.Move a sprite up across the screen. When: Move a sprite up across the screen. When it goes off the top of the screen, move it back to the bottom of the screen.
behavior_descriptions.move a sprite, changing its direction ra: move a sprite, changing its direction randomly
behavior_descriptions.move a sprite to the right across the sc: move a sprite to the right across the screen
behavior_descriptions.move a sprite downwards across the scree: move a sprite downwards across the screen
behavior_descriptions.move a sprite upwards across the screen: move a sprite upwards across the screen
behavior_descriptions.move a sprite to the left across the scr: move a sprite to the left across the screen
behavior_descriptions.move a sprite horizontally, reversing di: move a sprite horizontally, reversing direction if it touches the edges of the screen

https://studio.code.org/s/self-paced-pl-.short_instructions: Add an event to trigger the thrid move in the bird's dance.
https://studio.code.org/s/self-paced-pl-.long_instructions:
Teacher Tip: Remind students that behaviors do not stop until you tell them to with your code.

#### **Add another dance move with an event!** #### _(This is the code from your previous levels.)_ - #### Add a when right pressed event. - #### Connect a sprite begins block and choose a behavior to the new event. - #### Press Run and then **press the right arrow** to change the bird's dance moves. * * * #### **Bonus:** Add more events that trigger different dance move behaviors! [][0]

authored_hints.event: The new when right pressed event can be placed anywhere in the workspace.
authored_hints.event 2:
Be sure to choose a new behavior that is triggered by the event.

questions.text: Changes the look of a sprite
Sets the scene for the program
Makes something happen in a program based on an action like pressing a button
Simplifies complex code to animate programs

dsls.title: Check for Understanding: Behaviors

https://studio.code.org/s/self-paced-pl-.long_instructions:
## Let's Create!

#### It's time for you to put everything you've learned together and unleash your **creativity!**

#### Sprite Lab offers limitless possibilities to innovate and create, inspiring students to think outside the box and express themselves with code.

* * *

#### Watch this video to refresh your understanding of Sprite Lab's features, empowering you to craft your own unique adventure with code.

https://studio.code.org/s/self-paced-pl-.short_instructions: It's time to create whatever you want!
https://studio.code.org/s/self-paced-pl-.long_instructions:
Congratulations! You have learned the basics of event-based programming and now it's time to review what you know and start creating!
Note: The previous levels were customized to help you learn. This level gives you access to all of the features in Sprite Lab. Have fun exploring and trying out what the blocks do.


### **Use this level to practice creating with code.** #### _Not sure what to create? Some ideas could be a birthday card for a friend, recreating a scene from your favorite book or movie, or an all about me tutorial showcasing your favorite things!_
* * * #### **Here are some reminders to help you get started with your project:** - [ ] #### Begin by adding a set background block ##### _Remember, you can access the full background library by clicking 'backgrounds' and then the 'new background' icon._ - [ ] #### Add one or more new sprites to your code. ##### _Don't forget, you can access the full sprite library by clicking 'costumes' and then the 'new costume' icon._ - [ ] #### Add behavior blocks to make your sprites come to life. - [ ] #### Try adding more features to your project to make it even better. - [ ] #### Press the _Share_ button above to send your project to some friends!

callouts.costumes_tab: Click here to add costumes to your project.

dsls.markdown:
# Next Steps #### Thank you for completing **CS Basics: Creativity with Code.** Now that you've learned some basic computer science skills, check out some of our curriculum and professional learning offerings to continue your journey! ## Teach CS in your class #### Explore some of these curriculum options to get started teaching CS in your class right away. ## Continue learning #### Learn more about teaching CS with these self-paced professional learning modules.

## Help us make this module better! #### Code.org values and is responsive to feedback. Please fill out this short survey to provide your feedback on this module. Take the survey ## Stay connected * #### Continue participating in the Code.org teacher forum. * #### Connect with @teachcode on Twitter. * #### Join the Computer Science Teachers Association (CSTA).
